front.reference: Powder Metallurgy and Metal Ceramics, Vol. 49, Nos. 5-6, 2010

docTitle.titlePart:
ANODIC BEHAVIOR OF Al–Bi AND Al–Sb ALLOYS
IN 3% NaCl SOLUTION

byline.docAuthor: M. O. Krasovskii, 1 V. O. Lavrenko, 1,2 and L. M. Kostenko 1

front.div:
The methods of polarization curves and scanning electron microscopy are used to study the pitting
corrosion resistance of Al–Bi (up to 4 wt.% Bi) and Al–Sb (up to 20 wt.% Sb) binary alloys in a 3%
NaCl solution. With concentration of the alloying element to 0.1 wt.%, current density decreases and
corrosion slows down. With higher concentrations of antimony and bismuth, the early passivation
current density increases and the active region reduces on potentiodynamic curves. This indicates
that the corrosion resistance of aluminum alloys decreases with greater content of the other phase
(Bi or Sb).
front.keyword: Keywords: bismuth, antimony, aluminum, pitting corrosion, corrosion resistance, aluminum alloys.
front.div:
There are a number of studies [1–8] that focus on the anodic behavior of aluminum and its alloys in
different media. It is shown in [3] that high silicon content of aluminum alloy AA3005 increases its susceptibility to
corrosion. It turned out that iron content within an examined concentration range did not significantly influence the
corrosion susceptibility of the alloy. Copper promotes preferential dissolution, in which some areas of the corrosive
surface become rich in copper and, thus, act as cathodes that accelerate the corrosion process.
The pits resulting from the presence of intermetallic inclusions are identified as alkaline in [5]. Pits of this
type develop below the potentials of pitting formation (nucleation) and repassivation. Intermetallic inclusions that
serve as cathodes cause anodic dissolution of the matrix [6].
It is established in [7] that the density of cathode current decreases with increasing time before immersion
of a pure aluminum sample into a 1M NaCl solution. It is also suggested how an oxide film, which can heal defects
on pitting surface even at open-circuit potential, is formed. The formation of this oxide film is attributed to the
penetration of Cl
– ions into defective areas of the initial oxide film on the aluminum sample.
When pitting corrosion of aluminum in perchlorate solutions was examined using ac and dc current [8], it
was shown that the total anodic process could be divided into three stages based on potentiostatic measurements.
Stage 1 corresponds to the nucleation and growth of a passive oxide layer. Stages 2 and 3 involve the nucleation and
growth of pits. The pits nucleate after a certain incubation period, and the process becomes more intensive with
increasing concentration of ClO 4
– ions and step anodic potential.
